bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Robert P. Cooke, October 12, 1940

div1.p: Andrus writes to Cooke with questions regarding the yellow fever experiments and Agramonte's role. Cooke answers the questions in the spaces provided and adds a qualifying note.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Robert P. Cooke, October 12, 1940
div1.opener:
J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
10-12-40.
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Dr. Robert P. Cooke,
State Department of Health,
Lexington, Va.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
Thank you for your kind comments (of May 29) with reference
to the rough draft of my experiences in the yellow fever ex-
periments. Have collected additional data and am in quest
of still more. When I get the story in final form, will
send a copy to Dr. George B. Lawson, as you suggest.

There are some points I desire to clear up and I think you
know more about them than any other man living.

After Dr. Lazear's death, it is my belief that mosquitoes for
the earliest experimental cases were innoculated from cases
at Los Animas Hospital. Is that correct? Yes
Who innoculated the mosquitoes (early cases)? Carrol and or Agramonte
Who appliec the innoculated mosquitoes to volunteers on these
early cases? Carrol and Nimic

After experimental yellow fever had been produced at Camp La-
zear, it is my belief that all - or nearly all - of the mos-
quitoes used were innoculated from the experimental cases.
Is that correct? probably By whom? Carroll?
Who applied these innoculated mosquitoes to volunteers? ____

Who made the blood innoculations? Carrol?
WHERE were the blood innoculations made? At the Camp (Lazear)
(By the last question I mean were volunteers innoculated at
Camp Lazear or - as in my case - were they innoculated just
outside the yellow fever hospital - at Columbia Barracks -
and then, returned to Camp Lazear.)
Did Dr. Agramonte have any duties at Camp Lazear? no

For your convenience I have left space for answers so this
letter may be returned to me. If you care to elaborate
and to give additional data I shall appreciate it.

Had a nice latter a few days ago from Truby who retired as
a Brigadier General and is now living in San Francisco.
With kindest regards and every good wish,

As you know my association with the work was limited
to the period of the actual experiments in the buildings.
Before this I was on general duty at Camp Columbia and saw Major Reed and the others
only occasionally- About Jan 10th I was transferred to Puerto Prin (Principe)
my answer are only accurate as far as my memory goes
R P C
